title: How to Make Polish Dill Pickles

steps.headline: Wash the cucumbers.
steps.description: For the Polish dill pickles, you'll need 8 pickling cucumbers. Before you pickle them, though, it's important to remove any dirt and debris. Rinse the cucumbers in the sink under cold water to ensure that they're clean. Kirby cucumbers are an ideal pickling cucumber for making Polish dill pickles. Rinse the cucumbers thoroughly under the cold water, but don't use a vegetable brush. It can bruise them.

steps.headline: Cut off the cucumbers' blossom ends.
steps.description: There is an enzyme in the blossom end of cucumbers that must be removed because it can make the pickles dangerous to eat. Use a sharp knife to cut off a piece approximately 1/16-inch (1.6 mm) thick from the blossom end and discard. You can identify the blossom end of the cucumbers by looking for a rough dot. The stem end has a smooth, indented dot.

steps.headline: Chill the cucumbers in an ice bath.
steps.description: After you've removed the blossom ends from the cucumbers, fill a large bowl with cold water and ice. Place the cucumber in the bowl and allow them to chill until they become firm and crisp. It should take 15 to 30 minutes for the cucumbers to crisp up.

steps.headline: Wash and dry the jars.
steps.description: For the pickles, you'll need (2) 1 liter (0.26 US gal) (33.8 ounces) glass jars. Wash them thoroughly by hand with soap and water or in your dishwasher. Next, use a clean towel to dry the jars thoroughly. If you wash the jars in the dishwasher, check that all of the residue is removed.

steps.headline: Sterilize the jars in the oven.
steps.description: Once the jars are dy]ry, place them inside the oven on clean racks. Turn the heat to 225°F (110°C), and allow the jars to cook for 20 minutes before you fill them. After the jars have cooked for 20 minutes, turn off the oven but leave them inside until you're ready to fill them.

steps.headline: Divide the cucumbers between the jars.
steps.description: When you've finished sterilizing the jars, remove the cucumbers from the ice water bath. Place four of the cucumbers in each jar so they're evenly divided between the two. Traditionally, Polish dill pickles are made from whole cucumbers. However, you can trim the cucumbers to better fit in the jars if necessary. Try to keep each piece of cucumber the same size, though.

steps.headline: Add the dill, horseradish, garlic, mustard seeds, and peppercorns to the jars.
steps.description: For the two jars of dill pickles, you'll need 2 dill stems, 2 horseradish leaves, 2 small cloves garlic, 1 teaspoon yellow mustard seeds, and 4 to 5 peppercorns. Divide the spices evenly between the two jars, making sure to pack them in among the cucumbers. You can also some coriander seeds, bay leaves, and/or crushed red pepper flakes to the pickling mixture if you like.

steps.headline: Combine the water, salt, and vinegar.
steps.description: Add 4 ¼ cups (1 l) of hot water, 1 heaping tablespoon (50 g) of non-iodized salt, and 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of white vinegar to a medium saucepan. Use a whisk to blend the ingredients together so the salt starts to dissolve. The water should be hot but not boiling.

steps.headline: Bring the saltwater to a boil.
steps.description: Place the saucepan on the stove over medium-high to high heat. Allow the mixture to come to a full boil, which should take 7 to 10 minutes. Sti the mixture periodically as it boils to help the salt finish dissolving.

steps.headline: Cool the brining liquid and pour it into the jars.
steps.description: Once the brining liquid has come to a boil, turn off the heat and remove the pan the stove. Allow it to cool for 5 to10 minutes, and then divide the liquid between the two jars, making sure the cucumbers are covered.

steps.headline: Set the jars in a cool, dark spot for several days.
steps.description: Leave the lids slightly ajar, and set them in an area that is cool and doesn't receive much light, such as a pantry or basement shelf. Allow the pickles to ferment for 5 to 7 days. At the end of the initial pickling period, the pickles should still be crunchy and fresh in the center.

steps.headline: Chill in the refrigerator for 2 weeks.
steps.description: After you've allowed the pickles to ferment for about a week, close the jars. Place them in the refrigerator, and allow them to chill for at least 2 weeks to complete the pickling process.

text: Preparing the Cucumbers and Jars Wash the cucumbers. For the Polish dill pickles, you'll need 8 pickling cucumbers. Before you pickle them, though, it's important to remove any dirt and debris. Rinse the cucumbers in the sink under cold water to ensure that they're clean. Kirby cucumbers are an ideal pickling cucumber for making Polish dill pickles. Rinse the cucumbers thoroughly under the cold water, but don't use a vegetable brush. It can bruise them. Cut off the cucumbers' blossom ends. There is an enzyme in the blossom end of cucumbers that must be removed because it can make the pickles dangerous to eat. Use a sharp knife to cut off a piece approximately 1/16-inch (1.6 mm) thick from the blossom end and discard. You can identify the blossom end of the cucumbers by looking for a rough dot. The stem end has a smooth, indented dot. Chill the cucumbers in an ice bath. After you've removed the blossom ends from the cucumbers, fill a large bowl with cold water and ice. Place the cucumber in the bowl and allow them to chill until they become firm and crisp. It should take 15 to 30 minutes for the cucumbers to crisp up. Wash and dry the jars. For the pickles, you'll need (2) 1 liter (0.26 US gal) (33.8 ounces) glass jars. Wash them thoroughly by hand with soap and water or in your dishwasher. Next, use a clean towel to dry the jars thoroughly. If you wash the jars in the dishwasher, check that all of the residue is removed. Sterilize the jars in the oven. Once the jars are dy]ry, place them inside the oven on clean racks. Turn the heat to 225°F (110°C), and allow the jars to cook for 20 minutes before you fill them. After the jars have cooked for 20 minutes, turn off the oven but leave them inside until you're ready to fill them. Filling the Jars Divide the cucumbers between the jars. When you've finished sterilizing the jars, remove the cucumbers from the ice water bath. Place four of the cucumbers in each jar so they're evenly divided between the two. Traditionally, Polish dill pickles are made from whole cucumbers. However, you can trim the cucumbers to better fit in the jars if necessary. Try to keep each piece of cucumber the same size, though. Add the dill, horseradish, garlic, mustard seeds, and peppercorns to the jars. For the two jars of dill pickles, you'll need 2 dill stems, 2 horseradish leaves, 2 small cloves garlic, 1 teaspoon yellow mustard seeds, and 4 to 5 peppercorns. Divide the spices evenly between the two jars, making sure to pack them in among the cucumbers. You can also some coriander seeds, bay leaves, and/or crushed red pepper flakes to the pickling mixture if you like. Combine the water, salt, and vinegar. Add 4 ¼ cups (1 l) of hot water, 1 heaping tablespoon (50 g) of non-iodized salt, and 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of white vinegar to a medium saucepan. Use a whisk to blend the ingredients together so the salt starts to dissolve. The water should be hot but not boiling. Bring the saltwater to a boil. Place the saucepan on the stove over medium-high to high heat. Allow the mixture to come to a full boil, which should take 7 to 10 minutes. Sti the mixture periodically as it boils to help the salt finish dissolving. Finishing the Pickles Cool the brining liquid and pour it into the jars. Once the brining liquid has come to a boil, turn off the heat and remove the pan the stove. Allow it to cool for 5 to10 minutes, and then divide the liquid between the two jars, making sure the cucumbers are covered. Set the jars in a cool, dark spot for several days. Leave the lids slightly ajar, and set them in an area that is cool and doesn't receive much light, such as a pantry or basement shelf. Allow the pickles to ferment for 5 to 7 days. At the end of the initial pickling period, the pickles should still be crunchy and fresh in the center. Chill in the refrigerator for 2 weeks. After you've allowed the pickles to ferment for about a week, close the jars. Place them in the refrigerator, and allow them to chill for at least 2 weeks to complete the pickling process.
sentences: Preparing the Cucumbers and Jars Wash the cucumbers.
For the Polish dill pickles, you'll need 8 pickling cucumbers.
Before you pickle them, though, it's important to remove any dirt and debris.
Rinse the cucumbers in the sink under cold water to ensure that they're clean.
Kirby cucumbers are an ideal pickling cucumber for making Polish dill pickles.
Rinse the cucumbers thoroughly under the cold water, but don't use a vegetable brush.
It can bruise them.
Cut off the cucumbers' blossom ends.
There is an enzyme in the blossom end of cucumbers that must be removed because it can make the pickles dangerous to eat.
Use a sharp knife to cut off a piece approximately 1/16-inch (1.6 mm) thick from the blossom end and discard.
You can identify the blossom end of the cucumbers by looking for a rough dot.
The stem end has a smooth, indented dot.
Chill the cucumbers in an ice bath.
After you've removed the blossom ends from the cucumbers, fill a large bowl with cold water and ice.
Place the cucumber in the bowl and allow them to chill until they become firm and crisp.
It should take 15 to 30 minutes for the cucumbers to crisp up.
Wash and dry the jars.
For the pickles, you'll need (2) 1 liter (0.26 US gal) (33.8 ounces) glass jars.
Wash them thoroughly by hand with soap and water or in your dishwasher.
Next, use a clean towel to dry the jars thoroughly.
If you wash the jars in the dishwasher, check that all of the residue is removed.
Sterilize the jars in the oven.
Once the jars are dy]ry, place them inside the oven on clean racks.
Turn the heat to 225°F (110°C), and allow the jars to cook for 20 minutes before you fill them.
After the jars have cooked for 20 minutes, turn off the oven but leave them inside until you're ready to fill them.
Filling the Jars Divide the cucumbers between the jars.
When you've finished sterilizing the jars, remove the cucumbers from the ice water bath.
Place four of the cucumbers in each jar so they're evenly divided between the two.
Traditionally, Polish dill pickles are made from whole cucumbers.
However, you can trim the cucumbers to better fit in the jars if necessary.
Try to keep each piece of cucumber the same size, though.
Add the dill, horseradish, garlic, mustard seeds, and peppercorns to the jars.
For the two jars of dill pickles, you'll need 2 dill stems, 2 horseradish leaves, 2 small cloves garlic, 1 teaspoon yellow mustard seeds, and 4 to 5 peppercorns.
Divide the spices evenly between the two jars, making sure to pack them in among the cucumbers.
You can also some coriander seeds, bay leaves, and/or crushed red pepper flakes to the pickling mixture if you like.
Combine the water, salt, and vinegar.
Add 4 ¼ cups (1 l) of hot water, 1 heaping tablespoon (50 g) of non-iodized salt, and 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of white vinegar to a medium saucepan.
Use a whisk to blend the ingredients together so the salt starts to dissolve.
The water should be hot but not boiling.
Bring the saltwater to a boil.
Place the saucepan on the stove over medium-high to high heat.
Allow the mixture to come to a full boil, which should take 7 to 10 minutes.
Sti the mixture periodically as it boils to help the salt finish dissolving.
Finishing the Pickles Cool the brining liquid and pour it into the jars.
Once the brining liquid has come to a boil, turn off the heat and remove the pan the stove.
Allow it to cool for 5 to10 minutes, and then divide the liquid between the two jars, making sure the cucumbers are covered.
Set the jars in a cool, dark spot for several days.
Leave the lids slightly ajar, and set them in an area that is cool and doesn't receive much light, such as a pantry or basement shelf.
Allow the pickles to ferment for 5 to 7 days.
At the end of the initial pickling period, the pickles should still be crunchy and fresh in the center.
Chill in the refrigerator for 2 weeks.
After you've allowed the pickles to ferment for about a week, close the jars.
Place them in the refrigerator, and allow them to chill for at least 2 weeks to complete the pickling process.
tyn_section: (2) 1 liter (0.26 US gal) (33.8 ounces) glass jars with lids
